But it lasts all day and changes the way food tastes. I found it unbearable and stopped using the product after three days. It took another three days for the bitter taste in my mouth to go away.<br /><br />Oh, and the thing about relieving dry mouth? Never had an issue with dry mouth except during the short time I used this product.<br /><br />The annoying:<br />The packaging on this is wasteful, and it's designed to make you use more of it than you need. The dosage cup is about an ounce and it's just another piece of plastic for a landfill. The instructions tell you to rinse with one &#34;cup-full&#34;, then gargle with another full cup. Twice a day. That's four ounces a day from a 16 oz. bottle.<br /><br />Truth is, you can freshen your breath using much less than suggested in the instructions.   80. The real strength of this product is that it is very effective at removing tonsil stones.<br /><br />Certain people because of the shape of their tonsils, eating habits, etc. are more likely to get these \\"stones.\\" They are basically white little bits of hardened mucous / food / bacteria that form in and around your tonsils. I am not sure if it is entirely understood as to what causes them.<br /><br />They appear as white little dots on your tonsils. You can manually remove them with a toothbrush or cotton swab, but they also form in tiny little crypts in your tonsils as well and are difficult to remove without some form of mouthwash.<br /><br />I only even noticed that I had them one day when I coughed one of these tiny white specks up. They smell *horrible* and are the likely the main cause of chronic bad breath if you have it. A lot of people have them, but are unaware of them because they are usually pretty small, and are often hidden behind the folds in the back of your mouth. I brush twice a day, and still occasionally get them.<br /><br />After doing some internet research, the best advice I could find was to use an alcohol-free, saccharin-free mouthwash.<br /><br />I've tried a few different alcohol-free, saccharin-free mouthwashes: Biotene, Kiss-my-face, and this one. I'd give 5 stars to all three of the mouthwashes, because each one is fairly effective.<br /><br />Of the three, I have to say that the Therabreath mouthwash is probably the most effective at removing tonsil stones. Each time I used it, I noticed a few of the little 'stones' dislodging from my tonsils. You really do need to gargle it for about a minute though to achieve the maximum effect.<br /><br />The Cons to Therabreath are that the packaging, and the actual rinse itself gives you the impression that you are gargling some odorless chemical solution as opposed to mouthwash. It is also kind of expensive.<br /><br />If you have tonsil stones, I'd recommend first using Therabreath to dislodge all the stones, and then transitioning to another alcohol-free, saccharin free mouthwash that is cheaper and more pleasant to use, to prevent them from forming again.lcohol-free, saccharin free mouthwash that is cheaper and more pleasant to use, to prevent them from forming again.

Furthermore, my mouth feels cleaner and less heated on the inside.<br /><br />The reasons I don't give it a full five stars? I find their description of \\"neutralizing\\" to be far more accurate because your breath has more of a neutral scent than a fresh or minty one after using this. I would actually say that the rinse tastes like Hydrogen Peroxide to me (I have used HP in rinsing several times before), and that's the taste and odor I would say I am left with in my mouth all day and all night. I don't find this particularly pleasant. And as I mentioned being able to eat, drink and sleep, and wake up without bad breath...for example, if you drink Coke, the taste will linger on your tongue, but you can still also taste this rinse and as time goes by the taste of the rinse will again become more prevalent in your mouth. This would be fine if the rinse had a more pleasant taste.<br /><br />But I really can't complain much about the HP-like quality of the rinse. Before using this rinse, if I drank Coke, I would have bad breath until I brushed my teeth or rinsed with some rinse, and the bad breath would still come back. TheraBreath does what it's supposed to do in that regard, and I would rather walk around with HP-tasting neutrality in breath than bad breath, especially since I work in the public sector.'s supposed to do in that regard, and I would rather walk around with HP-tasting neutrality in breath than bad breath, especially since I work in the public sector.

  109. I have suffered from a breath \\"affliction\\" my entire life. I never knew of any non-surgical remedies for this. Awhile back, I discovered solutions for this problem area and have settled on TheraBreath as my choice brand. This has changed my life so much that I cannot count the ways. No longer am I embarrassed by seeing and hearing the reactions of people who catch a whiff of my malodor or even seeing them struggle to prevent from showing a reaction. True halitosis sufferers, you know what I mean.<br /><br />Please bear in mind that with this brand or other comparable brands, do not expect the taste to be easily palatable, at first. In no time, you will be used to it and will actually appreciate it. I use it twice a day along with the TheraBreath toothpaste and a tongue scraper (and flossing, of course). The process is not as long as you might imagine. My typical regimen is:<br /><br />1. Pre-rinse/gargle with TheraBreath oral rinse<br />2. Scrape tongue<br />3. Brush with TheraBreath toothpaste<br />4. Floss<br />5. Post-rinse/gargle<br /><br />I spend about 6-8 minutes both in the morning and before bed. IT IS SUCH A SMALL PRICE TO PAY to have a renewed sense of self-esteem and confidence in social dealings.<br /><br />I have experimented with what skipping a day or two would do by returning to just your normal popular brand oral care products. I can feel/smell my natural malodorous breath return quickly.<br /><br />I recently tried and then purchased the lozenges. They are merely small, individually wrapped breath mints but are GREAT to put one or two in the pocket when going out. You just take one when you feel your mouth begin to get dry. With other breath freshening gum and mints, you are frequently popping more trying to mask the scent. So you don't have to worry about carrying a bulky pack of gum, a roll of mints, or a can of Altoids. And one goes a LONG way. (For the record, I almost NEVER use them. I only keep one with me for \\"emergencies\\" but rarely feel the need to use it.)<br /><br />Dr. Katz's website is informative if you would like to learn more about it.<br /><br />Also, do not believe that this will give you permanent fresh breath. These products do not \\"mask\\" your breath like mouthwashes and gum do. It will ELIMINATE the REAL bad breath causing GERMS. If you do not keep up the daily use, those germs will grow back. But if you eat an onion sandwich or a squid-salad, that isn't bad breath... that's FOOD-breath.<br /><br />This review is not for those who just \\"believe\\" they have bad breath. This is for those who have suffered greatly the alienation that is felt with the affliction of chronic halitosis. I am writing this review in the hopes that it will help other sufferers like myself.uld like to learn more about it. Also, do not believe that this will give you permanent fresh breath. These products do not \\"mask\\" your breath like mouthwashes and gum do. It will ELIMINATE the REAL bad breath causing GERMS. If you do not keep up the daily use, those germs will grow back. But if you eat an onion sandwich or a squid-salad, that isn't bad breath... that's FOOD-breath. This review is not for those who just \\"believe\\" they have bad breath. This is for those who have suffered greatly the alienation that is felt with the affliction of chronic halitosis. I am writing this review in the hopes that it will help other sufferers like myself.

  111. According to the insert, TheraBreath works by specifically targeting the volatile sulfur compounds that form on the tongue and which are a major source of bad breath and chronic sour taste. While I've never had an issue with bad breath, I do sometimes have a sour taste in my mouth later in the day. I first bought TheraBreath several years ago, and I've been using it pretty consistently ever since.<br /><br />What's funny is that when you use TheraBreath for the first time, it doesn't taste or feel at all potent, like Listerine, Scope, Biotene, or the myriad other mouthwashes on store shelves. Instead, TheraBreath tastes like slightly minty water. Despite the underwhelming first impression, the product works; once the mint taste dissipates, you're left with a neutral taste in your mouth, and your breath smells like . . . well, like air. Also, you'll notice that your foods and beverages taste different, which indicates, at least to me, that the sulfur compounds on the tongue have a profound effect on our sense of taste, and that it's only when these compounds are removed that we're able to notice their effect.<br /><br />Overall, I gladly recommend this product.

At best, it seems to try to cover up bad smells with peppermint smell and numb your ability to smell/taste anything else. Dry mouths are harbors for sulfur-producing bacteria causing bad breath.<br /><br />I was at my wit's end trying to find a solution for this. I somehow stumbled upon Therabreath, a company that creates multiple products to solve this frustrating problem. It's almost as if the inside of my lips have been rubbed raw; any acidic or alcoholic food or beverage causes a burning sensation when it touches my lips. I stopped using the mouthwash for a few days to see if it really was the cause of my dry lips, and my lips did start to feel better, but then my tonsil stones and bad breath came back without the mouthwash to fight them off. I now feel dependent on this mouthwash to keep my tonsils clear, but I'm worried that means I will have dry, irritated lips for the rest of my life.   280. I am on my fourth bottle of TheraBreath oral rinse. I've also tried the TheraBreath toothpaste and mints, because I was initially so impressed by the oral rinse. I cannot rate this with 5 stars however, because I acknowledge what many other reviewers have already stated, that it affects how water tastes for a few hours afterward. I have not noticed this so much as a metallic flavor, as others have said, but more like baking soda. It feels as if the oral rinse makes my mouth very alkaline and thereby negatively affects how things taste. However, the rinse does make my mouth feel clean and fresh and not dry. I have determined to simply use it less frequently. I can only theorize that the reason there are such polarized reviews for this product on Amazon is that it works relative to the pH balance of the person using it. So perhaps for those who really need it, it is very effective. And for those who have different body chemistry, the rinse is overkill and leaves them with a metallic aftertaste or sore throat? For what it's worth, even with the unpleasant effect afterward, I have continued to use this rinse. And I have never experienced an allergic reaction or sore throat. The rinse is very plain; it almost feels as if you're rinsing with water. There is no strong, discernible flavor. But it seems to be effective at freshening breath.

  287. I don't remember how we found out about Therabreath, but so glad we did. My husband had bad breath that regular mouth wash was not working for. This product works to rid the tongue of those sulfur compounds that end up living on your tongue.<br /> Bad breath is caused by the excretion of the anaerobic bacteria that live within your mouth. These anaerobic bacteria (bacteria that do not need oxygen to survive) excrete sulfur compounds. These sulfur compounds ignite the bad-breath brushfire. The rotten egg smell (hydrogen sulfide) and the barnyard smell (methyl mercaptan) are known as VSCs – volatile sulfur compounds. The key word here is volatile.<br /> So you treat it with this alcohol free mouthwash. Yes it costs more than average mouth wash, BUT.. having fresh breath is worth it for yourself and for those that have to smell the bad breath, that was ME.<br />My husband uses the tongue scraper along with the mouth wash on most days. If he slips and does not use it I can tell , and I remind him to use it. Don't forget to take it on vacation!!<br />I highly recommend this product with those of you with BAD breath.<br />He has used it for many years, and I make sure he does NOT run out.

I have instead been filling the cap to the first line, which is about 8 mL, and doing each (which still creates a lot of bubbles), with good results. And that will allow it to last almost a month.<br /><br />Update: I found a better way is to fill to the line on the cap (15 mL) and combine rinsing and gargling in one step. As I said, the gargling fills my mouth with bubbles, so I gargle, then rinse to decrease the bubbles, then gargle, etc. Works well. And makes the bottle last a month.<br /><br />Update update: I have been now filling it to a line just underneath the suggested line, which is about 8 mL, with good results. I have also found I don't need to do it every day. So my advice is experiment and you can make this product last awhile and still give great results.

Most mouthwashes (even the alcohol-free ones) have an acidic pH, which can erode tooth enamel over time... Citric acid is an ingredient in most of them. Also, bad bacteria don't grow as well at the alkaline pH. I love the subtle mint flavor, too. There seem to be two schools of thought here: One says antibacterial is bad; in mouthwash or even household surface cleaners because the germs that survive the pass are the strongest and they are left to multiply so your problem gets even worse. The other school of thought says this is not the case. Personally, I like to go on the attack. So I'm all for antibacterial stuff. I just use twice the amount or use it for twice as long. If Listerine or BreathRx says to swish for 30 seconds, I'm doing is for 1 minute.<br /><br />Because Therabreath doesn't have anti-bacterial ingredients - I will still use something like BreathRx Antibacterial before bed to kill germs. I don't care for the super-powerful \\"Clean Mint\\" flavor, but I figure it gets the job done, and it gets great reviews on Amazon. In the morning before going out, I'll use Therabreath. And then I can really get my mouth feeling and tasting the way I want it to, the way I love it to.<br /><br />Ahhh, I just want to rinse with it again right now!<br /><br />TL;DR - Best tasting/feeling breath ever, a tad pricey but well worth the investment.   765. I tried this product because I needed a new mouthwash, was in the mood to try something besides the usual Crest, Listerine, etc., and because this product was #1 in its category and received amazing reviews and testimonials. I don't have issues with bad breath per se, but like anyone, I don't exactly wake up in the morning with minty clean breath, so I thought it couldn't hurt to try the product. About 10 days later, I quit it, and was honestly just as excited to stop using TheraBreath as I was excited when I first got it.<br /><br />For me, at least, I did notice an improvement in how my breath smelled. But, I also experienced side effects that overwhelmed the benefits. First of all, as others have noted, this product changed how food and drink tasted. I noticed this especially with coffee and tea--at first I thought there was something wrong with the water filter I was using, as these drinks were suddenly tasting somewhat minerally and just ... off. Then I noticed the issue in general with not only drinks but food. Everything tasted muted, and mildly unpleasant. The bottle warns you not to eat or drink for 5 minutes after using the product, but I experienced these side effects throughout the day. Moreover, my mouth was constantly dry and my tongue felt a bit \\"hairy\\". I developed a sore throat and cough that took weeks to get over ... the latter issue might not have been related to the product, but in reading some other reviews I'm not so sure ... I got better shortly after quitting the product.<br /><br />TheraBreath gets many great reviews, so I have to believe it works for some people. If my breath was so bad that it was a major social or professional concern, perhaps I would've put up with the side effects or hoped that they'd go away with time. But, as someone just looking for a mouthwash that would keep their breath relatively fresh, the side effects simply were not worth it. I have to think that for most people, a \\"regular\\" mouthwash will do just fine ... I was happy to go back to Crest after using this product for a little bit, and am happy to enjoy the taste of food and drink again. So again, this product appears to work for many people ... but I'd advise a little bit of caution based on my own experience at least.t fine ... I was happy to go back to Crest after using this product for a little bit, and am happy to enjoy the taste of food and drink again. So again, this product appears to work for many people ... but I'd advise a little bit of caution based on my own experience at least.

  1212. First, this product does what it promises: it does not sting or burn, and it does leave the mouth feeling clean and fresh. I expect it is a godsend for those with severe halitosis. I like that it's American made, not tested on animals and comes packaged like an old-fashioned private label product your town pharmacist would make up in the back of the store. The price is fair and it gives good value. It works.<br /><br />The reason I deactivated my subscription is that using this product temporarily leaves a strong metallic taste in my mouth that interferes with enjoyment of everything I eat or drink, even plain water. It's like a combination of baking soda, peppermint and stainless steel that won't go away. It works okay used in the evening for slightly less than the recommended one minute, then rinsed a minute later with plain water, when I'm not going to eat for about 9-10 hours. I made the mistake of trying it twice in one day and decided it would make a great weight loss aid - made food taste terrible. It took two days for this lingering after-taste to disappear. So it all depends on your priorities - odorless breath or the pleasures of good eating.
